item.title: A Playbook for the Autonomous Party
item.description:
A Playbook for the Autonomous Party: A Data-Driven, Systems-Based Approach to Political Power

I. Foundational Principles: From Protest to Power

A. Synthesizing the “No Kings” Ethos: An Electoral Mandate for Anti-Authoritarianism

The foundation of a viable new political entity rests on a clear and resonant core identity. The “No Kings” movement provides a potent and timely ideological framework. This movement is defined by its mobilization of a diverse coalition 1 united by a “massive, visible, nonviolent, national rejection” of perceived authoritarianism.1 Its participants are not bound by a single policy but by a shared set of principles: a commitment to nonviolent action 3, a defense of democratic norms, and a clear rejection of autocratic rule, encapsulated in the slogan that America does not have “absolute rulers”.1

item.title: Ads Are Making US Sick
item.description:
Ads are Making US Sick: How the Advertising Economy Created a Public Health Crisis and Why AI is the Next Frontier

Part I: The Architecture of Unhealth: Psychological Manipulation and Public Health

Section 1.1: The Sickness: A Social Determinant of Health

The pervasive critique that television and other media are “unhealthy” often mistakes the medium for the message. Media formats, in themselves, can be powerful tools for education, connection, and well-being.^[1] The central thesis of this report is that the economic model underpinning this media—a system funded by persuasive advertising—is a primary vector for public unhealth. This system does not merely correlate with poor health outcomes; it actively perpetuates them.
